Yes, parallel editing can also be used effectively in love stories to heighten the emotional stakes and create tension. In fact, there are many romantic films that use parallel editing to show multiple events happening simultaneously.

For example, in the film "The Notebook" based on Nicholas Sparks' novel, parallel editing is used to show two different time periods of the same love story. The film cuts back and forth from the 1940s to the present day, showing the young couple falling in love and their older selves rekindling their romance. The use of parallel editing adds emotional depth to the story and allows the viewer to see the parallels between the two time periods.

Another example is "La La Land". In the final scene, parallel editing is used to show two different versions of the love story between the two main characters. One version shows what could have happened if they stayed together, while the other shows the reality of their separate lives. The use of parallel editing adds to the emotional impact of the scene and brings a bittersweet quality to the story.

These examples show that parallel editing can be used effectively in romantic films to create tension and emotional resonance. By cutting back and forth between different events, filmmakers can create a heightened sense of anticipation and keep the audience engaged in the story.
